If one relies on the Chengshi school,
the mind arises sequentially,
and it is not said that it relies on each other simultaneously and abides.
It is only said that the mind and consciousness rely on the other four aggregates,

Because it clings to objects, it is called innate craving.

Since innate craving pervades the four minds,

Consciousness is first.
It is only said to be the abode of consciousness.
The rest can be understood by analogy.
Therefore, it is not fully discussed.
Second, using the weak to illustrate the strong.
Among the four minds,
the consciousness mind that grasps the nature is the weakest.
Up to the volitional formations mind that grasps the nature is the strongest.
Using the weak to speak of abiding,
the stronger can be understood.
Therefore, it is omitted and not discussed.
Third, it is named abode of consciousness in order to refute non-Buddhists who say that consciousness relies on a soul.
This is because non-Buddhists often take the mind and consciousness to rely on the self-nature.
